text:
Hi this is David from MinuteEarth in a special
collaboration with Bill and Melinda Gates.
The human brain is a frustrating thing.

On the one hand, it has the analytical power
to do the science to develop the tests and
treatments and vaccines we need to stop COVID.

On the other hand, it’s often irrational
and makes us think and act in ways that help
the virus spread.

Here are four of those cognitive biases that
have made the pandemic worse.

First, we humans tend to underestimate a disease’s
ability to spread.

We intuitively process “growth” as linear:
if one thing happens today, and one thing

happens tomorrow, then we assume that another
thing will happen the next day and - by the
end of a month - 30 things will have happened.

But infections like COVID can spread exponentially,
so if one person is sick today and another

gets sick tomorrow, the day after tomorrow
four people could be sick, and by the end
of the month, millions of us could be sick.

The difference between this and this is HUGE
- and it's the reason why many of us can't

imagine - or can't believe - that we need
to take such strict precautions.

What’s more, our biased brains not only
underestimate the risk of any one person getting

sick - we also underestimate the chances that
that one person is us!

Ideally, in a pandemic, everyone should act
pessimistically - like they're likely to get

infected (or already are) - but that kind
of thinking doesn’t come naturally to us.

Humans are - by nature - optimists; Evidence
shows that we think we're above average as

far as intelligence, and less likely than
average to get in a car accident.

So it's no surprise that many people underestimate
their likelihood of getting COVID - and act
accordingly.

The problem is, this overly optimistic behavior,
when taken by lots of people, causes the virus
to spread more quickly.

We humans also have a bias against our future
selves . We’re generally able to take stock

of things and decide that temporary inconveniences
like steering clear of each other outweigh

temporary pleasures like - well - not steering
clear of each other can help stop the pandemic
sooner.

But, in the moment, our brains’ desire for
instant gratification means that we sometimes

justify doing what we want - even if that
screws over “future us”.

And finally, we humans don’t like being
told what not to do.

When we hear - especially from an authority
- “Don’t see your family” or “Don’t

leave your house without a mask,” the primitive
parts of our brains sense a threat.

We get mad and become more likely to do the
opposite…even when we know the guidelines
will help limit the spread of disease!

This effect is especially strong in places
where “me” is valued over “we”.

Even worse, once our hackles are raised, we’re
more likely to buy into dangerous misinformation.

Luckily, we humans have also identified some
ways to combat our misguided instincts.

Studies have found that regular reporting
on the spread of the disease has helped people

estimate risks and positive reinforcement
from friends and family has helped people
stay the course.

So perhaps the rational parts of our brains
could be the key to fighting the irrational
parts of our brains.

In other words, that which can fight viruses
can also fight biases.

We are really excited to have partnered with
Bill and Melinda Gates on this video - and

to help them get the word out about their
annual letter about important global challenges.

As you might expect, this year it's mostly
about the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

They point out that everyone in the world
is connected by a microscopic network of germs—so,
like it or not, we’re all in this together.

In addition to discussing how we can mitigate
some of the worst fallout from this pandemic

- through equitable vaccine distribution and
a huge investment in getting stalled educational

opportunities back on track - they also dig
into how we can prevent the next pandemic.

That includes a global alert system that can
quickly spot new threats, mega diagnostic

platforms that can test 20% of the world’s
population every week, and improved monoclonal

antibody treatments and vaccines that can
be rapidly deployed around the world.

Check it out at GatesLetter.com or by clicking
the link in the description. Thanks!
